post.title: Independent monitors found benzene levels after Harvey six times higher than guidelines

children.text: Data based on private air sampling sponsored by Environmental Defense Fund and Air Alliance Houston shows a more nuanced picture than the one given by the EPA about one of the most toxic chemicals.

"When Hurricane Harvey blew in," Manchester resident Guadalupe Hernandez tells ProPublica, "the stench [of chemical smells] became noticeably stronger for about five hours, a scent like 'glue or boiled eggs.'"
But, ProPublica continued, "The Environmental Protection Agency assured the public

in the area a week after the storm hit, and spent several days taking air pollution measurements with a mobile laboratory. The agency didn’t release any specifics, but said concentrations of several toxic chemicals, including the carcinogen benzene, met Texas health guidelines."

Private testing, though, revealed "a more nuanced picture." Elena Craft, a senior health scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, which sponsored the monitoring with Air Alliance Houston, told ProPublica that the concentrations were "higher than usual" and "concerning."
She said, “Did we actually capture the highest concentrations that blew into the neighborhood or not? We don’t know.”
